H0.text: It makes food easier to find, which is why the ash borer moth’s wasp‑like appearance helps the moth survive.

H1.text: Predators avoid the ash borer moth because it resembles a wasp yet lacks stinging ability, helping the moth survive.

H2.text: It aids in attracting a mate because the ash borer moth looks similar to a wasp but does not have the ability to sting, and this adaptation most likely helps the moth survive.

H3.text: The moth blends in with its surroundings because the ash borer moth looks similar to a wasp but does not have the ability to sting, an adaptation that helps it survive.

A4.text: The more toxic the model is, the more likely it is that the predator will avoid the mimic.

A5.text: The abundance of the model species is also important for the success of the mimic because of frequency‑dependent selection. When the model is abundant, mimics with imperfect model patterns or slightly different coloration from the model are still avoided by predators.
